user.biography: Inspiration and information about what works in education. Produced by the George Lucas Educational Foundation.

node.text: Here are 4 mindsets teachers can adopt to reframe math as a creative, empowering tool that’s relevant to everyday life.

node.title: How to Ease Math Anxiety in the Classroom

node.text:

node.title: Which Reading Strategies to Try, and Which to Ditch

node.text:
Distractions, confusing material, or an overwhelming amount of information can tax a student’s working memory. Here are tips that can help.

#WorkingMemory #ClassroomTips #TeacherTips #InTheClassroom #EducationResearch

node.title: How to Optimize Working Memory in the Classroom

node.text:
Getting to know all your students at the top of a school year can be overwhelming. One idea? Ask their families to tell you all about them, in a playful assignment called "In a Million Words or Less."

The Million Words activity originated with teacher Deb Bova on the MiddleWeb site in 2003, but has thousands of variations.

Link in bio. 

#FamilyEngagement #BackToSchool #StudentEngagement #BackToSchoolActivity #TeacherTip #TeacherTips

node.title: Getting to Know Your Students in a Million Words or Less

node.text:
As you return to school, think about starting a new routine or ritual that welcomes students to class every day. Not only will it help with classroom management, but students will be more focused, grounded, and ready to learn.

#WelcomeBack #BackToSchool #MorningRoutine #TeacherTip #TeachersOfInstagram

node.title: Starting Each Class With A Warm Welcome

node.text:
Educator Shana White discusses how she uses art to bring every student's identity into the classroom. "Identity portraits are a project that allows kids to express their own identities. It's a really big growth point for a lot of kids that they are able to be comfortable with who they are and recognize and respect the identity markers of anybody." 🖌

#Diversity #CulturallyResponsiveTeaching #SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #Arts #ArtEducation

node.title: Exploring Perceptions About Identity Through Self-Portraits

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 7 people, people standing and road.

node.text:
Every Friday, some students in Modesto, California aren’t met by a big yellow school bus, but by the smiling faces of their teachers and support staff who walk them to school.

Staff from Bret Harte Elementary School and Hanshaw Middle School meet at the elementary school for a light breakfast, and then by 7:35 AM, they begin walking to meet students. While some families find the group along the way, pulling over in the car to let their children join in, others are assisted with crossing the street or even welcomed with a friendly knock on their front door in the morning. Between 25 to more than 100 families, students, and staff participate, on average, each Friday.

According to Bret Harte Principal Marla Conteh, the initiative has not only helped improve attendance, but has bolstered the relationship with the surrounding community. 

“Our Bret Harte staff wanted to connect with families and scholars on a more personal level and walking to school together was the perfect way to make this happen,” said Conteh. “We hope our Peace Path will promote wellness, scholar attendance will increase, and families will feel valued and welcomed by our Bret Harte staff.”

#BackToSchool #WalkingToSchool #WalkToSchool #TeachersOfInstagram #EducationNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Edutopia on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Inspi Inspirati ting in Nek me Open cultuu Creativity mine ral SOCIAL & EMOTIONAL LEARNING (SEL) Promoting Prosocial Behaviors in the Classroom'.

node.text:
When prosocial behaviors like kindness and empathy are nurtured in school, research shows it does more than make class a happy place, it also improves academic outcomes. “Each time we do a prosocial act, our brain releases chemicals that make us feel good, and those same chemicals enhance learning,” writes English teacher Cathleen Beachboard. ⁣
⁣
Here are three prosocial behaviors to teach and model in the classroom.⁣
⁣
1. Practice gratitude: Feeling gratitude over time increases a person’s overall mood, research shows. Set aside time regularly for kids to jot down things in a journal that they’re grateful for and encourage mindful reflection by asking them to reread previous entries. Or dedicate a special spot on your bulletin board for students to post notes of gratitude to each other. “Model the behavior by writing positive notes to students for specific acts, and posting the praise,” Beachboard suggests.⁣
⁣
2. Encourage kindness: Acts of kindness can increase compassion and lead to deeper classroom connections. Model kindness by giving authentic compliments in class and encourage students to deliver praise to peers. Ask students to write cards welcoming new kids to school. Or try a “jar of joy” project where students fill containers with positive messages, stories, and motivational quotes and then give them to friends or family members who need support or cheering up. ⁣
⁣
3. Develop empathy: Giving students opportunities to share vulnerabilities and dreams can “create bridges of empathy and understanding” between classmates and allow them to see how much they have in common, says Beachboard. Have students create a collage of positive memories, dreams, and aspirations. Or try identity portraits, collages that represent “who they are and their future goals,” Beachboard suggests. Display students’ projects in class and organize a gallery walk followed by a class discussion where kids share similarities and connections they noticed among the projects. 

#SEL #SocialEmotionalLearning #ProsocialBehaviors #BackToSchool
